===Role ethics===
  +
{{main|Role ethics}}
  +
Role ethics is an ethical theory based on [[family]] roles.<ref name="Ames">{{cite book|author=Roger T. Ames|title=Confucian Role Ethics: A Vocabulary|date=30 April 2011|publisher=University of Hawaiʻi Press|isbn=978-0-8248-3576-7}}</ref> Unlike [[virtue ethics]], role ethics is not individualistic. Morality is derived from a person's relationship with their community.<ref name="Fraser">{{cite book|author1=Chris Fraser|author2=Dan Robins|author3=Timothy O'Leary|title=Ethics in Early China: An Anthology|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Z2Qqf6ZXxh0C&pg=PA35|date=1 May 2011|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|isbn=978-988-8028-93-1|pages=17-35}}</ref> [[Confucianism|Confucian]] ethics is an example of role ethics.<ref name="Ames"/> Confucian role ethics centers around [[filial piety]] or ''xiao'', a respect for family members.<ref name="Chang">{{cite book|author1=Wonsuk Chang|author2=Leah Kalmanson|title=Confucianism in Context: Classic Philosophy and Contemporary Issues, East Asia and Beyond|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_UC1mvUKaU8C&pg=PA68|date=8 November 2010|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-1-4384-3191-8|page=68}}</ref> According to Roger Ames and Henry Rosemont, "Confucian normativity is defined by living one's family roles to maximum effect." These roles are established as human relationships, and morality is determined through a person's fulfillment of a role, such as that of a parent or a child. Confucian roles are not [[rationalism|rational]], and originate through the ''xin'', or human emotions.<ref name="Fraser"/>
